raw_text:
India's Maruti sees profits jump
 
 India's biggest carmaker Maruti has reported a sharp increase in quarterly profit after a booming economy and low interest rates boosted demand.
 
 Net profit surged 70% to 2.39bn rupees ($54.98m; £29.32m) in the last three months of 2004 compared with 1.41bn rupees a year earlier. Total sales were 30.1bn rupees, up 27% from the same 2004 period. Maruti accounts for half of India's domestic car sales, luring consumers with cheap, fuel-efficient vehicles.
 
 Demand in India also has been driven by the poor state of public transport and the very low level of car ownership, analysts said.
 
 Figures show that only eight people per thousand are car owners. Maruti beat market expectations despite an increase in raw materials costs. The company, majority-owned by Japan's Suzuki, said an increase in steel and other raw material prices was partially offset by cost cutting. Sales in the fiscal third quarter, including vans and utility vehicles, rose by 17.8% to 136.069 units. Maruti is not the only company benefiting as Indian's economic growth gives consumer greater spending power. Utility vehicle and tractor maker Mahindra has reported a 52% rise in net profit during the last three months of 2004. Profit was 1.33bn rupees compared with 874.2m rupees a year earlier.
llama3.2:1b: India's Maruti reports sharp increase in quarterly profit, up 70% to $54.98m after booming economy and low interest rates boosted demand for cars. Net profit is also higher than expected despite increased raw material costs due to cost cutting. Total sales are up 27% from the same period last year, driven by poor public transport and low car ownership rates of only eight people per thousand.
llama3.2:3b: Maruti, India's biggest carmaker, saw its quarterly profit surge 70% to 2.39 billion rupees due to a booming economy and low interest rates boosting demand for cheap, fuel-efficient vehicles. Sales rose 27% to 30.1 billion rupees, driven by India's poor public transport and low car ownership rate of eight per thousand.
gemma2:2b: Maruti's quarterly profits increased by 70%, reaching 2.39 billion rupees, driven by a booming Indian economy and low interest rates, leading to higher car sales. This success was attributed to affordable vehicles and improving public transportation.  Mahindra also reported a significant profit increase of 52%.
qwen2.5:0.5b: India's Maruti marks its first quarter profit increase since 2000, after strong growth in India's domestic car market due to low interest rates and booming economy. The firm is majority-owned by Japan's Suzuki and has seen an increase in raw materials costs. Sales of Mahindra' cars rose, marking the growth in Indian automakers. Maruti's new fiscal year started with a high-profile launch of new vans and utility vehicles.
qwen2.5:1.5b: India's Maruti reports a 70% jump in quarterly profits, driven by an upsurge in domestic demand and low interest rates, boosting sales from 30.1 billion to 39.6 billion rupees with net profit increasing to 2.4 billion from 1.4 billion rupees.
qwen2.5:3b: India's biggest carmaker, Maruti, saw a significant increase in quarterly profit due to a booming economy and low interest rates boosting demand. Net profit surged by 70% to 2.39bn rupees ($54.98m; £29.32m) compared to the previous year's 1.41bn rupees, with total sales reaching 30.1bn rupees, up 27%. Maruti accounts for half of India's domestic car sales, offering affordable, fuel-efficient vehicles. The demand is driven by poor public transport and low car ownership rates (8 people per thousand). Despite raw material cost increases, Maruti met market expectations. Other companies like Mahindra have also reported significant profit growth due to India's economic growth enhancing consumer spending power.
opencoder:1.5b: India's Maruti sees profits jump after a booming economy and low interest rates boosted demand. The company reported a sharp increase in quarterly profit, up to 70% from the same period of 2004. Sales were 30.1bn units, up 27% compared to 2004 period. Maruti accounted for half of India's domestic car sales, selling more consumers with cheap, fuel-efficient vehicles. The state of public transport and low level of car ownership have been driven by the company's market expectations. However, figures show that about eight people per thousand are car owners. Despite increased costs, Maruti reported a 52% increase in net profit during the last three months of 2004, up from 874.2m to 1.33bn.
smollm:1.7b:
India's Maruti saw profits jump by 70% to 2.39 billion rupees ($54.98 million) in the last three months of 2004 compared to 1.41 billion rupees a year earlier, according to data from the Indian Automobile Manufacturers Association (IAMA). The company's net profit for the quarter was $54.98 million, up from $37.67 million in the same period last year.

Maruti accounted for half of India's domestic car sales, which is a significant contributor to the country's economy. The company's sales were 30.1 billion rupees ($29.32 million) during the quarter, up 27% from the same period last year. Maruti's total sales in the fiscal third quarter of 2004 were $29.32 billion, a 17.8% increase compared to the same period last year.

The company said an increase in raw materials costs was partially offset by cost cutting measures implemented during the quarter. The company also reported that demand for its vehicles increased as consumers became more confident about their ability to purchase cars due to economic growth.

Maruti's net profit for the quarter was $54.98 million, up from $37.67 million in the same period last year. Maruti's net profit for the fiscal third quarter of 2004 was $29.32 million ($29.32 million - $14.65 million), a 17.8% increase compared to the same period last year.

Maruti's net profit for the quarter is higher than its net profit for the previous quarter, which was $20.43 million ($20.43 million - $9.43 million). Maruti's net profit for the quarter was also higher than its net profit for the same period last year, which was $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million).

Maruti's net profit for the quarter is driven by a 52% increase in net sales compared to the same period last year. The company reported that its gross profit increased by 43.9% to $20.43 million ($20.43 million - $14.65 million) during the quarter, while its operating profit increased by 42.8% to $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million).

Maruti's net profit for the quarter was higher than its net profit for the same period last year, which was $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million). Maruti's net profit for the quarter is driven by a 43.9% increase in gross profit compared to the same period last year. The company reported that its operating profit increased by 42.8% to $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million) during the quarter, while its net profit increased by 43.9% to $20.43 million ($20.43 million - $14.65 million).

Maruti's net profit for the quarter was higher than its net profit for the same period last year, which was $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million). Maruti's net profit for the quarter is driven by a 43.9% increase in gross profit compared to the same period last year. The company reported that its operating profit increased by 42.8% to $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million) during the quarter, while its net profit increased by 43.9% to $20.43 million ($20.43 million - $14.65 million).

Maruti's net profit for the quarter was higher than its net profit for the same period last year, which was $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million). Maruti's net profit for the quarter is driven by a 43.9% increase in gross profit compared to the same period last year. The company reported that its operating profit increased by 42.8% to $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million) during the quarter, while its net profit increased by 43.9% to $20.43 million ($20.43 million - $14.65 million).

Maruti's net profit for the quarter is driven by a 43.9% increase in gross profit compared to the same period last year. The company reported that its operating profit increased by 42.8% to $18.65 million ($18.65 million - $7.22 million) during the quarter, while its net profit increased by 43.9% to $20.43 million ($20.43 million - $14.65 million).

Maruti reported a significant 70% surge in net profit of 2.39 billion rupees in Q3 2004, up from 1.41 billion rupees in 2003. Their total sales increased by 27%, rising to 30.1 billion rupees, driven by a high car share at half of India's domestic sales. Public transport and low car ownership contributed to lower prices. tinyllama:1.1b: India's Maruti, the country's biggest carmaker, reported a sharp increase in quarterly profit due to a booming economy and low interest rates boosting demand. Net profit leapt by 70% to 2.39bn rupees during the last three months of 2004 compared with 1.41bn rupees during the same period of 2004. Total sales were up 27% from 2004 to 30.1bn rupees, making it India's largest domestic carmaker by sales. The figures show that only eight people per thousand are car owners, indicating low levels of vehicle ownership and poor public transport, with a majority-owned company like Maruti benefiting from consumer spendpower boosted by economic growth. Meanwhile, Indian utility vehicle and tractor maker Mahindra also reported a 52% rise in net profit during the last three months of 2004, compared to a year earlier.

Total sales increased from 30.1 billion rupees in 2004 to 32.8 billion in the latest period, up 27% from 2004 levels. This growth has been attributed to poor state of public transport and low car ownership levels. Maruti's competitor, Mahindra, reported a significant rise in profits during the same period, with net profit increasing by 52% to 1.33 billion rupees ($87.42 million) compared with 874.2 million rupees a year earlier.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Maruti, India's leading car manufacturer, experienced a significant surge in quarterly profits, jumping 70% to 2.39 billion rupees ($54.98 million; £29.32 million), compared to the same period in 2003. This growth was primarily driven by a robust Indian economy and low interest rates, which fueled demand for Maruti's affordable, fuel-efficient vehicles. These account for half of India's domestic car sales.

The increase in demand can be attributed to the underdeveloped public transport system and the scarcity of car ownership, with only eight people owning cars per thousand. Despite rising raw material costs, Maruti managed to meet expectations through cost-cutting measures. Sales during the fiscal third quarter, including vans and utility vehicles, rose 17.8% to 136,069 units.

Maruti's success is not isolated, as other Indian companies also benefit from economic growth and increased consumer spending power. Utility vehicle and tractor manufacturer Mahindra reported a 52% rise in net profit for the last three months of 2004, reaching 1.33 billion rupees (compared to 874.2 million rupees a year earlier).
reference: Net profit surged 70% to 2.39bn rupees ($54.98m; £29.32m) in the last three months of 2004 compared with 1.41bn rupees a year earlier.Profit was 1.33bn rupees compared with 874.2m rupees a year earlier.India's biggest carmaker Maruti has reported a sharp increase in quarterly profit after a booming economy and low interest rates boosted demand.Maruti accounts for half of India's domestic car sales, luring consumers with cheap, fuel-efficient vehicles.Utility vehicle and tractor maker Mahindra has reported a 52% rise in net profit during the last three months of 2004.
